subject: Gardening
title: Bones of the Garden: Evergreen Structure
description: A quick win: understand Bones of the Garden: Evergreen Structure.

hook.text: Remove all the flowers from a great garden and the design still holds. That's because the bones are strong.

buildup.text: Garden 'bones' are permanent structural elements: hedges, walls, paths, evergreen trees, and architectural plants.

discovery.text: Evergreen structure ensures the garden has form in winter. Without it, the space collapses into brown emptiness.

twist.text: The best test of garden design: photograph it in January. If it still looks designed, the bones are working.

climax.text: Start every garden design with structure. Add perennials and flowers lastâ€”they fill in the framework, not create it.

punchline.text: Photograph your garden in January. That's your real design.

quiz.question: What is the 'bones' test for good garden design?
options: Checking if the soil has enough calcium for plant growth
Photographing the garden in January to see if structure holds without flowers
Testing whether the garden survives strong winds without damage
